essentially did was um the goal is to basically say you know the interactive queries tend to be
short in nature and users don't always know which ones they are and they can't really cue them appropriately so we said
okay we have to figure this out on behalf of the user so it respective of what cues the queries land on we will
detect the queries that we think are short and automatically bump up their priority to the front of the
queue uh and this I mean overall you'll see that this leads to better throughput because the short queries get get ahead
it gets it doesn't get stuck behind the long running queries and it's able to improve overall throughput of the system
as well as the interactivity uh the second thing we did
again for the same use case is what we call the power start uh essentially in
this case every every query the every new query that gets to a compute node uh gets a bump in resources we give it some
extra resources and say okay see if you get done so that you can be out of the queue and out of our
slots um and of course even in this case the short running queries will actually
just finish and leave the queue while uh the longer guys will get swapped
out and really the trade-off here is you know a query that's that takes 10
seconds or 5 Seconds you don't want it to wait behind one that takes 45 minutes you'd rather move it up front and have
the one that would take 45 minutes take 48 minutes because it's unlikely to actually
matter uh the third thing we did was Q hopping this one's already available uh
in this case essentially we give you a mechanism to specify a timeout per queue

components there's one about encryption and uh we support data encryption uh at
rest in the source which is an S3 you can encrypt your data on S3 uh data is encrypted as it as it makes its way into
red shift using TLS and we support elliptical curve ify Helman for forward security and then within red once it
lands we again encrypt your data at a block level we actually do an envelop encryption scheme where every block of
data is encrypted using a separate key all these keys are encrypted using a cluster key and then the cluster key is
encrypted using a master key and this is basically to allow you to rotate keys without re-encrypting your
data and also the master key can either be supplied by us using our key stores
or it can be supplied by an HSM of your choice uh HSM is a Hardware security model in which case we would have to go
to the HSM every time you wanted to access the database to get the keys to go access this data
uh we use Amazon VPC for Network isolation and uh rely on uh cloud trail
for uh audit and uh logging so these would be the three pillars for having security and as you can see we are
compliant with a number of Standards including uh fed ramp and
Hippa but security is a is is a thing that keeps evolving there are new things there are new threats and new features

it's possible to Now Grant your cluster uh permissions for your S3 buckets
